To implement the evaluate function in manifold and get the tests passing again, I need to first understand the current state of the manifold class and the evaluate function. I'll start by reading the manifold.hpp file to see the function declaration and any relevant comments.
{"tool":"readFile","path":"include/shap/manifold.hpp","content":"/workspaces/shap/include/shap/manifold.hpp"}

The manifold class is a template class that maps from parameter space to target space. It has a pure virtual function evaluate that needs to be implemented. The function takes a parameter point and returns a geometric point containing full geometric information. I'll need to implement this function in a way that makes sense for the manifold class.

To get a better understanding of how the evaluate function should be implemented, I'll take a look at the geometric_point.hpp file.
{"tool":"readFile","path":"include/shap/geometric_point.hpp","content":"/workspaces/shap/include/shap/geometric_point.hpp"}

The GeometricPoint class bundles geometric information about a point on a manifold. It has a constructor that takes a manifold, a local position, a world position, and a vector of derivatives. The class also has accessors for the manifold, local position, world position, and derivatives.

To implement the evaluate function in the manifold class, I need to create a GeometricPoint object and return it. The GeometricPoint object requires a manifold, a local position, a world position, and a vector of derivatives. The manifold is the current object, so I can use the this pointer. The local position is the parameter point passed to the evaluate function. The world position and derivatives need to be calculated based on the parameter point and the manifold.

I'll start by calculating the world position. This will depend on the specific manifold, so I'll need to add a virtual function to the manifold class to calculate the world position.

Next, I'll calculate the derivatives. This will also depend on the specific manifold, so I'll add another virtual function to the manifold class to calculate the derivatives.

Once I have the world position and derivatives, I can create a GeometricPoint object and return it.

I'll add the virtual functions to the manifold class and implement them in the derived classes.
manifold is an attempt to generalize surface.hpp to also support paths. it should use function objects rather than virtual functions.

The user wants the manifold class to use function objects instead of virtual functions. This means that the manifold class should store a function object that calculates the world position and another function object that calculates the derivatives.

I'll modify the manifold class to store two function objects: one for calculating the world position and one for calculating the derivatives. The evaluate function will then use these function objects to calculate the world position and derivatives.

I'll also modify the constructor of the manifold class to take the two function objects as parameters.
